title: Stress and Physical Pain
content: Stress can show up as physical pain. Higher levels of cortisol can lead to physical pain in the body.

title: Adjusting to New Time Zones
content: Adjusting to a new time zone can be done by slowly adjusting bedtime and wake schedule over the course of 10 days. This helps the internal clock adjust to the new time zone.

title: Heat and Cold Therapy
content: Heat and cold therapy can impact lifespan or healthspan. However, they are separate topics and should not be lumped together. Heat therapy has been linked to resistance to cardiovascular disease and mortality, improved endothelial function and arterial stiffness, improved walking ability and lower limb perfusion, improved glucose metabolism, improved autonomic nervous activity, cerebral protection, and stress resistance.

title: Cold Therapy for Delayed Onset Muscle Soreness (DOMS)
content: Cold therapy can help reduce DOMS. The greatest benefits to reducing DOMS occur when treated 24 to 72 hours post exercise. Treatment should not be administered in the first hour post exercise. However, cold therapy could reduce inflammation, which is beneficial post-exercise. If inflammation is overly suppressed, it could blunt some muscle hypertrophy.

title: Cold Therapy for Depression or Immune Enhancement
content: It is possible, but far from established, that cryotherapy could alleviate the symptoms of depression. The immune system’s response to cold stress is not yet fully understood. Some studies have shown that cryotherapy decreases inflammation, although not all results agree. If cryotherapy is addressing chronic inflammation, that’s one thing, but from the acute perspective, that inflammation might be doing something that’s ultimately beneficial.

title: Cold Therapy and Brown Adipose Tissue (BAT)
content: The role of cold therapy in relation to brown adipose tissue (BAT) is a topic of research.

title: Brown Adipose Tissue (BAT) and Health
content: Brown adipose tissue (BAT) is more metabolically active and therefore it becomes another energy consumer suggesting that having more BAT may increase the calories you’re burning. Metabolically healthy people have more BAT than less metabolically healthy people. Cold exposure activates brown adipose tissue. Increasing BAT increases energy expenditure which could help with obesity, insulin sensitivity, metabolic health. BAT secretes 'batokines'—bioactive peptides and proteins which have potential health benefits such as cardioprotection via FGF21 and IL-6, preservation of beta cells in the pancreas, fatty acid oxidation in the liver, and inhibition of myostatin.

title: Cold Therapy and Health
content: Cold exposure activates sirtuins in brown adipose tissue and heat shock proteins, similar to exercise. However, there isn’t much evidence that cold exposure increases longevity. Cold therapy includes cryotherapy, plunging (ice bath), and cold exposure (mild, prolonged cold exposure). Cold water immersion has the most risk associated with it, mostly due to afterdrop, which occurs when your core temperature drops from something safe, like 96-97, to 92-93, which could result in a ventricular arrhythmia.

title: Heat Therapy and Health
content: Heat therapy enhances sleep, decreases pain, reduces risk of cardiovascular disease, improves endurance and performance, decreases risk of dementia and Alzheimer’s Disease, decreases risk of respiratory disease, and improves insulin sensitivity and glucose control. The physiological effects of heat therapy include increased GH levels, increased prolactin in both sexes, increased cortisol immediately after heat therapy which drops to baseline by 1-2 days after and decreases from 3-7 days, and a likely increase in other biomarkers.

title: Sauna Use and Longevity
content: A study out of Finland comparing different frequencies of sauna use found that more frequent sauna use was associated with lower all-cause mortality, fatal cardiovascular disease, sudden cardiac death, fatal coronary heart disease, stroke, and Alzheimer’s disease. The most benefit was conferred by at least 20 minutes in the sauna, at least 172 to 174 Fahrenheit/80 degrees Celsius, and at least four times a week.

title: Alzheimer’s Disease Risk Reduction
content: Alzheimer’s disease reduction: 3% absolute risk reduction. Given avg. age starting age was 53 and followed for 21 years makes them 74—which means this is probably undercounting what the potential is for Alzheimer’s risk reduction—so as this cohort gets older you could see more data related to Alzheimer’s disease.

title: Healthy User Bias
content: Healthy user bias is one of the biggest challenges that epidemiologists face when they try to make associations into causations. For example, eating a vegetarian diet requires a lot of effort. So by definition, a person who could put that much effort into what they ate and didn’t eat could put a lot of effort into other things that could positively influence their health. Therefore, it’s hard to infer health benefits associated with the absence of meat as opposed to the presence of these other things.

title: Sauna Studies Limitations
content: Heart rate increase could possibly just be a marker, not a “maker”, of health. Heart rate may increase up to a hundred beats a minute during moderate sauna bathing sessions and up to 150 beats per minute during more intense, warm sauna bathing. That sounds very similar to what happens when a 50-year-old engages in endurance exercise.

title: Multivariate Adjustment in Sauna Studies
content: In the multivariate adjustment, they adjusted for the following covariates: Age, BMI, systolic blood pressure, LDL cholesterol, smoking, alcohol consumption, previous MI, type two diabetes, cardiorespiratory fitness, resting heart rate, physical activity, and socioeconomic status.

title: Possible Mechanisms Conferring the Longevity Benefits of Sauna
content: Overall, the data is robust in support of heat therapy in the following manner: Dry sauna, 20 minutes or more each session, Four times a week or more, At about 170 degrees Fahrenheit/80 degrees Celsius. Possible mechanisms conferring benefit: Mimics exercise—This type of sauna activity seems to mimic cardiovascular exercise. E.g., Heart rate gets up to 150 beats per minute in a sauna.

title: Hormonal Changes in Sauna
content: There are increased growth hormone levels, Increased prolactin, Increased cortisol, And other hormones likely increase: norepinephrine, renin activity, white blood cell count, and heat shock proteins.

title: Personal Sauna Regimen
content: Five times per week, 60 minute sessions. He personally really enjoys it. He feels mentally and intellectually stimulated (almost like a “runner’s high”).

title: Opportunity Cost of Sauna
content: Does Bob think there’s an opportunity cost of spending so much time in the sauna when he could be exercising? Bob personally does not feel there to be an opportunity cost. In fact, he finds it a tad challenging to engage in a similar amount time in zone 2 exercise (which presumably is the closest type of exercise to dry sauna). As a bonus, he can be more “productive” in the sauna (e.g., reading papers) as compared to during exercise.

title: Final Takeaways on Sauna
content: Prior to this big analysis done by Peter and his team, Peter never really viewed sauna as having any longevity benefit. But now, Peter is ready to add sauna into his tool kit for longevity. That said, exercise is probably giving you many of the same benefits. In fact, Peter would place exercise above sauna as exercise comes with a number of benefits that sauna doesn’t including (but not limited to) stability and structural benefits and some of the mitochondrial fuel partitioning benefits.
